discussion.content:
I don't think this one is correct. The question is "... vulnerabilities with lower CVSS scores may get a higher priority if they are easier to implement ... ". Let's assume the CVSS Score is 7 for a minute:

A. Hard: 7 * 0.1 = 0.7
 Easy: 7 * 1 = 7
B. Hard: 7 * 5 = 35
 Easy: 7 * 1 = 7
C. Hard: 7 / 1 = 7
 Easy: 7 / 10 = 0.7
D. Hard: (7 * 2) / 1 = 14
 Easy: (7 * 2) / 5 = 2.8

So, A is the only correct answer imho. Can anyone else comfirm?

The issue with what Acrisius is doing is stating that 2 is easy and 8 is hard when the scale of answer C clearly states that 10 is easy and 1 is hard. (he got his scale wrong). Blind_hatred got his scale right and also the right answer. A

An organization uses Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores to prioritize remediation of vulnerabilities.

Management wants to modify the priorities based on a difficulty factor so that vulnerabilities with lower CVSS scores may get a higher priority if they are easier to implement with less risk to system functionality. Management also wants to quantify the priority. 

Which of the following would achieve management's objective?

 Take a CVSS score of 8 High
 Divide this by a difficulty score of 2. So its easy to do. 
 You get a priority of 4

 Take a CVSS score of 10 - Critical
 Divide this by a difficulty of 8. So its harder to do. 
 You get a priority of 1.25

So the lower CVSS score actually get higher priority than the high score. 

Score range Severity rating
0.0 None
0.1-3.9 Low
4.0-6.9 Medium
7.0-8.9 High
9.0-10.0 Critical

So C is the answer.. 
C. (CVSS Score) / Difficulty = Priority Where Difficulty is a range from 1 to 10 with 10 being easiest and lowest risk to implement



I really dont like these questions :-(

comments.content: Makes sense to me, that’s exactly what the question is asking for: a scoring system where low risk vulnerabilities get higher priority to drive up remediation metrics. Not sure why this would be a viable strategy but good to know it’s something someone might want

Thanks. Makes sense and I think that is the right answer, just one note, CVSS scores is not really equal to risk. We can never quantify a risk/envi to a specific number since there is too many factor to consider, we can only say quantitative risk like high, moderate or low. There are many resources talking about this. Just my two cents.

https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/why-cvss-does-not-equal-risk-how-think-about-risk-your-environment

discussion.content: How can it be A? Hard = 0.7 while easy = 7 C... Hard = 7 while easy = 0.7... My 2 cents...
exactly, the same thing i got from my calculation. A is the only correct answer

questions.question_text:
An organization uses Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores to prioritize remediation of vulnerabilities.
Management wants to modify the priorities based on a difficulty factor so that vulnerabilities with lower CVSS scores may get a higher priority if they are easier to implement with less risk to system functionality. Management also wants to quantify the priority. Which of the following would achieve management's objective?

choices.D: ((CVSS Score) * 2) / Difficulty = Priority Where CVSS Score is weighted and Difficulty is a range from 1 to 5 with 5 being easiest and lowest risk to implement
choices.C: (CVSS Score) / Difficulty = Priority Where Difficulty is a range from 1 to 10 with 10 being easiest and lowest risk to implement
choices.A: (CVSS Score) * Difficulty = Priority Where Difficulty is a range from 0.1 to 1.0 with 1.0 being easiest and lowest risk to implement
choices.B: (CVSS Score) * Difficulty = Priority Where Difficulty is a range from 1 to 5 with 1 being easiest and lowest risk to implement

choices.C: Encrypt all of the traffic between the scanner and the endpoint
choices.B: Provide each endpoint with vulnerability scanner credentials
choices.A: Install agents on the endpoints to perform the scan
choices.D: Deploy scanners with administrator privileges on each endpoint

questions.question_text: A security analyst is attempting to configure a vulnerability scan for a new segment on the network. Given the requirement to prevent credentials from traversing the network while still conducting a credentialed scan, which of the following is the BEST choice?

discussion.content:
I have handled Qualys and I'm not sure how to encrypt the traffic from the scanner and endpoint, have not seen related settings for this also.
But why not just install the agents and have them run with the appropriate permissions, credentials wont be traversing to/from the scanners and endpoints in this way.

comments.content: Encrypted or not, the credentials would still transfer over the network. By installing agents on the endpoints, you wouldn't need credentials at all.

discussion.content: My instinct is C. Can someone explain why it is something else besides C

choices.A: Verify the vulnerability using penetration testing tools or proof-of-concept exploits.
choices.D: Configure a network-based ACL at the perimeter firewall to protect the MS SQL port.
choices.C: Mark the result as a false positive so it will show in subsequent scans.
choices.B: Review the references to determine if the vulnerability can be remotely exploited.
choices.E: Implement the proposed solution by installing Microsoft patch Q316333.

questions.question_text:
File integrity monitoring states the following files have been changed without a written request or approved change. The following change has been made: chmod 777 ""Rv /usr
Which of the following may be occurring?

discussion.content: A and D are incorrect since chown is the command in changing permissions. B is also incorrect since no functions have been locked. C is the nearest answer although not worded properly, but the directory/files with 777 permissions will give read, write and execute permissions to everyone or "world" lol

choices.D: The ownership of/usr has been changed to the root user.
choices.B: Administrative functions have been locked from users.
choices.A: The ownership pf /usr has been changed to the current user.
choices.C: Administrative commands have been made world readable/writable.

discussion.content:
Guys please search the meaning again.

APT: stealthy threat actor, which gains unauthorized access to a computer network and remains undetected for an extended period, they are persistent/only attacks one org at a time.

But a opportunistic attack can still install new software to endpoints right? Even a penetration tester can do that, even I and you can do that c'mon. That is needed in post explotation phase.

0 day: a vuln even the vendors doesn't know about that is why its a zero day you will start counting from that day it is discovered, that is the reason why it is not detected by endpoint security.

Please dont answer or base your judgement just because it asks for Threat and T from APT is Threat lol thats hilarious.

comments.content: bro, threats use vulnerabilities, its asking for the threat, so APT, stop teaching people when u dont know what youre saying

discussion.content: The key in this questions is "installation of new applications" which APT can do.
I think is zero day, APT normally runs for a long period without being Identified

I disagree here... An APT is typically described as an attack over time from foreign soil... which is possible here, but I think the MOST likely would be Zero Day based on the evidence given... Change my mind.

comments.content: I agree. Leaning on APT for this one.

Zero Days are vulns that have not yet been mitigated. Question asks for Threat which would suit APT most :) Additionally it mentions the use of new software etc which would signify APT as Zero Days aren't installations of apps.

questions.question_text: A production web server is experiencing performance issues. Upon investigation, new unauthorized applications have been installed and suspicious traffic was sent through an unused port. Endpoint security is not detecting any malware or virus. Which of the following types of threats would this MOST likely be classified as?
